subject: RE: [junit] RE: Why doesn't JUnit count asserts
msgSnippet: ... Well, the test is a placeholder. Obviously, you should be worried about it if you forget to come back and fill it in. When I do this sort of thing, I use
messageBody:
Keith Ray wrote:
> The following test case has no assertions...
> public void testSomeThing()
> {
> // fill in this code someday... in the meantime,
> // give everyone a false sense of security because
> // this counts as a passed test.
> }
> ...should I be worried that this test isn't good enough?

Well, the test is a placeholder. Obviously, you should be worried about it
if you forget to come back and fill it in.

When I do this sort of thing, I use this pattern:

public void testSomething() {
// fill in this code someday... in the meantime,
// give everyone a false sense of security because
// this counts as a passed test.

Calendar dueDate = new GregorianCalendar(2001, Calendar.JULY, 26);
Calendar now = new GregorianCalendar();
assert("This test should have been implemented by now"
now.before(dueDate));
}

I typically set the date either one day or one week ahead, depending on how
many test placeholders I make at a time.

I use these placeholder tests as the equivalent of PostIt notes reminding me
of something I don't wish to forget.

Robert.

--
"Duct tape is like the Force: it has a light side, a dark side,
and it holds the universe together"
Robert Watkins robertdw@... robertw@...
